Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the videos show the China-India border standoff in June 2020. The expert's verdict provides evidence that the videos were circulating online before the June 2020 border conflict.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the videos, as they were found to have been previously published on YouTube in 2014 and 2017, suggesting that they may not be related to the specific border standoff in June 2020.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the videos were not related to the June 2020 border standoff, as they were circulating online before the conflict occurred.
Understate: The claim may understate the significance of the videos by presenting them as evidence of the China-India border standoff in June 2020 when they are actually unrelated.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing accurate information about the videos and their relevance to the June 2020 border standoff.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim.
